comment.author: 77235581@N00
comment._content: His full name was Albert Webber Jones, born in St Georges-in-the-East (London). Albert enlisted at Stratford. His CWGC record can be viewed here.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: This picture was taken at the photographic studio of C S Scott at 53 Leytonstone Road, Stratford, Essex (now in the London Borough of Newham).//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Albert Webber Jones, b. 1892, son of George (1869) and Rosetta (1877) Jones of 42 Ely Terrace, Mile End Old Town.  Albert at age 19 is shown on the 1911 census to be employed as a painter.  He had younger siblings - Rosetta Louise, b. 1899; and George William, b. 1901.  His father was a self-employed 'wood chopper', working from home.  Their 4 room house also accommodated a lodger, John Bowen, b. 1862, a dock worker, and his infant daughter, Kate, b. 1910.

109th Battery RFA was equipped with 6 x 18pdr QF guns.  In 1914 it was initially part of the Regular XXIII Bde RFA and went to France in August 1914 with 3rd Division.  On 15 Apr 1916 109th Battery was regrouped with 107th and 108th Battery to be 281 (1/2 London) Brigade RFA; but on 10 May 1916 was regrouped again into 283 (1/4 London) Brigade RFA, with 93 Battery under Lt Col Wainwright.  This organisation provided artillery support to 56(London) Division on the Somme for their attack on Gommecourt on 1 Jul 1916.  At some point after the Battle of the Somme 109th Battery was returned to 281 (1/2 London) Brigade RFA.

Albert Webber Jones, No 64728, was initially trained and employed as an Artillery Driver, working with the horses that pulled the guns and ammunition limbers.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Albert Webber Jones enlisted as a Volunteer.  He arrived in France on 26th September 1915.  [National Archive WO/372/11].

On the morning of 28th March 1918, to the North of Arras, 56(London) Division bore the impact of Ludendorff's 'Mars' Offensive which was intended to widen the breach in the British Third Division created by the 'Michael' Spring Offensive.  This was preceded, as elsewhere, by intense and accurate counter-battery artillery fire.  56(London) Division, in well dug-in positions, ultimately repulsed this attack.

The 281 Brigade War Diary has one entry for 28th March 1918:  "0620 - 109 suffer casualties."  It would appear that 109th Battery had 12 or 13 men killed, (which likely also means they had around another 30 men wounded).//
